A tiny hole to fill with slaves and squeeze warpstone from.
More tunnels, more slaves, but this mine is still barely fulfilling your greatest needs, o Mighty Leader!
This warpmine doesn't just have useless slaves to work in, it has the great and excellent machines!
This mine has been dug deeper and deeper, the tunnels reinforced and extended to squeeze as much warpstone as possible.
Many slaves die each day in the dark abysses of this warpmine, but the results are more than worth it!
Countless slaves die each day in the dark abysses of this warpmine and plenty of machines twist and melt under the changing forces of the precious mineral, but the results are more than worth it!

The wiser among Ogre Tyrants realised that while hunting and eating trade caravans can be profitable, a much better long-term solution is to tax them. Traders pay a toll for safety and live, Tyrants get more wealth. Everyone is happy. In addition, traders do bring valuable technology, which can lead to more wealth.

Maneaters are ogres who have spent a reasonable part of their lives as mercenaries in the armies of the weaker humans. Those that come back are most valuable to a Tyrant, as they bring with them vast combat experience and represent the pinnacle of "tactical expertise" among ogres. As they maneaters are more "civilised" than other ogres, visiting traders will find negotiations easier. Being great caravan guards, they make trade more profitable on the whole trade route.
A mobile garrison accompanies the caravans from this outpost on their journey through Araby.

Here, slaves are corraled into various stocks and pens, awaiting their fates, whether it be to die toiling in mines, dying in battle, or worse yet, becoming another plaything for their new Druchii masters.
Here the slaves of Naggarond toil in the mines. They provide essential labor for their Druchii masters, extracting the resources they need to build their grand cities and temples.
Here the slaves of Naggarond toil in the fields. They provide essential labor for their Druchii masters, harvesting the food they need to survive.
Home to the Black Ark Corsairs, these ports are bustling with trade, but most of the trade that does go on is between slavers and their products.
The magic of the old ones permeate the jungles of Lustria. The hidden trails of the lizardmen are marked by totems of this ancient power.
A garrison of veteran warriors keep vigilance over the gates to the underway and the surrounding area. While small bands of scouts patrol the tunnels of the deep road.

Norscan Whalers are not just typical hunters, they are also well-abled warriors. Since whaling is an important trade for Norsca, Whalers are respected even among the warriors due to the extreme dangers of the waters surronding Norsca. Swimming through the dark currents of the Sea of Claws are massive whales, many of which bear strange markings, and odd colouration, twisted and warped as they are by the power of Chaos. These monsters can capsize ships and swallow hundreds of men in a single gulp. Thus, Whalers must be made of sterner stuff than ordinary fishermen
Strigany are masters of the art of trade, and here is where it is done. If merchants and travellers don't come to the Strigany to trade, the Strigany will come to them.
These lands are vast, and mostly untouched by settled civilization. Perhaps we would encourage nomads to move into this province, and levy them into our army for future wars.
The need to retain Strygos' independance and security means that Strygan fortresses are designed to house large amounts of soldiers and withstand severe punishment from beseiging armies.

Strygan cities are fortresses in their own right. Built out of necessity, they are built to withstand everything from greenskin migrations to Bretonnian crusades. Even with the Badlands under the control of the greenskins, the ruins of old Strygos have endured to this day. We can replicate the masterworks of old Strygos and build these new fortress cities in our provinces, so that we may never fall again.

Strygans are masters of defense, and Strygan Murder-Gates are their magnum opus. Utilising a maze-like network of defensive walls and gates, Strygans are able to corral invaders through a gauntlet of withering fire from above while creating the impression that respite is just around the next corner. But it's not, boiling tar is.

One of the mightiest city-states of Tilea, Miragliano is always assailed by the plagues and insidious ratmen coming from the Blighted Marshes to its west. As a result, the city itself is highly fortified, with walls specially designed to give maximum advantage to artillery firing from it, and towers that never crumble even when leaning at near-comical angles. These excellently planned fortifications are the results of the sponsorship of engineering, science and other arts by the Princes of Miragliano. Thus, it is not surprise that this was the city to give birth to the genius inventor and engineer, Leonardo da Miragliano.

Remas is the greatest and most ancient city in Tilea. It is home to a huge circular port, said to have been built when the city was still a High Elf trading post, and even in the ruined and dilapidated state it is now, it still houses the powerful Reman fleet. A great bridge links the city proper to the port, and also houses many businesses and the fine palaces of the merchant princes. Remas proper is laid out on a grand scale within a long circuit of defenses, and protected by mercenary companies of pikemen that fight in the ancient style.

Many prosperous cities outgrow their walls. In Verezzo's case, the solution has been to build up, rather than out, creating the tallest city in the realms of men. The towers of the Verezzan elite can be seen from miles around. Architects and engineers rarely want for work in this inventive city.

Built on the ruins of an ancient Elven citadel, strengthened by Dwarf masons, and manned by some of the toughest mercenaries in the Old World: Monte Castello is one of the most formidable fortresses in Tilea.

Luccini is the great city of Southern Tilea. Great armies of pikemen march under the Leopard banner of its princes and merchants flock to the city's markets. Luccini is also a religious center, with many temples standing atop the Acropolis at the city's heart.
Small but elegant, Pavona is famous for the many bridges which allow its privileged upper class to spend their lives literally above the common masses.

Trantio is a relative newcomer to the games of the Tilean Princes. For centuries it was a backwater, isolated from the main trade routes and only able to secure its independence from Remas and Miragliano by masterfully playing one off against the other. In more recent times the explorer Marco Colombo installed himself as Prince and wisely invested Lustrian treasure in the city. What next for Trantio?

Here are where the sellswords reside, lightly armored swordsmen, usually made up of deserters from foreign lands, impetuous duelists and other scoundrels, usually hired to protect the flanks of Pike and Crossbow regiments.

Tilean Pike and Crossbow regiments are trained here. Each regiment has a long history, and many record their services as as mercenaries as well as professional soldiery with pride. The Tilean Princes will usually employ these kind of companies as the mainstay of their personal armies.

Tilea is a mountainous and hilly region, unbefitting of horse warfare, so most Princes don't train or equip any kind of horsemen in their personal armies. Instead, they employ Freelancers, made up from robber knights and disgraced nobles, usually from Bretonnia, the Empire or Kislev. They make up a strong heavy cavalry formation, most of the time.

Ogres are known to sell themselves are mercenaries for payment, adventure, and above all, food, meaning they are very easy to maintain. A camp of Ogres has been established in this province, allowing the ruler to raise heavy shock troops in times of war. These Ogres however, are not very fond of cannons.

Tilea's terrain does not allow for larger cannons that the Dwarf and Imperial armies field, so much more emphasis is put on mobility rather than caliber. This does not make them any less deadly, or any less louder for that matter.

The main keeps of Myrmidian fortresses are usually ostentatious palaces built by its myriad of Princes. While they lack the typical garrison of armoured footmen and free riders of other realms, they make up with a veritable army of philosophers, painters, sculptors and other polymaths seeking patronage, who make the abodes of these princes into true cultural - and financial - centers.

Tilea and Estalia are lands of invention and innovation, full of bright scientists and brilliant artists whom toil day in and day out for their masterworks. The City Forum is the nexus of all activities artistic, scientific, and most especially political.

While most cities focus almost entirely on scientific and artistic pursuit, all cities do field a small detachment of citizen militia units. Armed with pikes and crossbows, and drilled by a seasoned mercenary captain, Tilean citizen units can be expected to hold their own against most foes.

The Condottieri are semi-professional mercenaries that hire themselves out to those who offer the highest pay. Many cities hire Condottieri to train their soldiers and to augment their forces with veteran gunpowder forces, however they are notoriously unreliable allies and are known to be very unsavory.

The Inventor's Guild is massive, with a significant clout of political power in the southern half of the old world, organizing local scientists and artists into groups and unions to better control the spread of technology, and of course, to earn a fortune selling said technology. An inventor's guild house can produce anything from fine arts to near-magical armors and weapons

This marketplace is a fusion of northern Imperial sophistication and southern Arabyan splendour, merchants sell a vast array of goods, from locally grown produce and spices, to the steam inventions of questionably sane scientists.

This port is a fusion of northern Imperial sophistication and southern Arabyan splendour, but on a much grander scale than the ground-bound marketplaces, accepting goods from as far south as the Southlands and as far east as Pigbarter.

The Monasterio Bellus is the main administrative building of a temple dedicated to Myrmidia, goddess of the art of war. Worship of Myrmidia is most confined to Tilea and Estalia, but her influence can be seen as far north as Ostermark and Ostland, and as far south as Sudenburg. Those who follow and invoke her name are professional soldiers and mercenaries, for her domain is on the art of war.

The Castro Caelesto is where the heavenly warriors dedicated to Myrmidia are housed, whos lives they willingly give to the goddess of the art of war. Heavily armed, fanatically devoted to Myrmidia, these holy warriors can act as shock troops during holy wars.

The Sacruii Thesauruo, or Sacred Armoury, is where the blessed weapons, armor, and seals are kept. Many chapters, cults, and brotherhoods of Myrmidia are venerable in age, and thus the weapons and other effects found here are venerated for the great and holy acts they've taken part of.

The Ludo Bellicia, or School of War, is the most famous establishment of all Myrmidian monasteries, where the famous Ars Bellicia is taught to all brothers of the faith, regardless of whether or not they are part of the local chapter or not.
An Estalian-Tilean based Chapterhouse has established itself in this monastery, providing it with heavily armoured pikemen and crossbowmen.

Every town, village, city, and thorp has at least one watering hole. Old Worlders like to forget about their miserable lives, the present threat of death, and their general dissatisfaction with lords and their kind. Taverns offer men and women a place to escape, to laugh, sing, and swap stories, and a place to spend hard-earned coppers in the company of friends.
The lands around the hold are suitable for sprawling farms, interspersed with villages and manors.

The rocky hills and cliffs make for good defensive terrain, and naturally lead to mining and quarrying. Although not nearly as effective as Dwarf techniques, a good amount of ores, gemstones and fine building stone can be extracted.
The forbidding woodlands are not as safe as one would like, but logging, hunting and farming can be very productive.
The hot, dry lands are hard to work, but those with the right techniques can prosper.
The cold, fierce lands of the north bring hard winters and short summers, but breed equally tough people.
The wide, open lands make for poor crops, but great numbers of horses and ponies can be raised for industry or war.

Khypris, the city of splendours, is a massive trade city located in the borderlands, once the capital of the grand Khyprote empire in ages past. While the empire is long gone from most human memory, the power and prestige of the city remains, and as such is considered the greatest city between Myrmidens and Akendorf.

Akendorf, once the captial of a long lost Imperial borderlands Elector-County, is the center of all Imperial influence in the borderlands, straddeling the boundry of what the Imperials consider the 'civilized' world, it is a city that is constantly under threat. Not just from the Orks of the badlands, or Goblins from the mountains, but from the inummerable Beastman tribes that inhabit the foreboding Stygian Woods. Due to this, Akendorf is considered the weakest between Khypris and Myrmidens.

Myrmidens is the second largest city-state in the Borderlands, capital of the Aegean Principality, one of the sucessor states of the Myrmidan Empire. The days of Myrmidias' Empire are long gone, but the proud and civic traditions it left behind are still strong, reflected in Myrmidens' strong, yet elegant walls, designed to impress and intimidate would-be conquerors and foreign diplomats. Dealings with Dwarf holds have increased Myrmidens' importance not only as a trading hub, but also as a technological and military center, as both Human and Dwarf work closely with each other to stamp out the Greenskin threat to the south.

Khypris (formerly the Capital of the vast Khyprian Empire) is one of the original Kingdoms of the Borderlands, once reaching to the tip of the Black Mountains and comprising of the three provinces of the Northlands, the Heartland and the Westland's. While the age of the khyprote empire is long gone, the city still remains a wondrous site on the region, and heavily controls trade in the region.

Akendorf has an electoral-monarchy system in which leaders are voted into power, Akendorf's nobles run an electoral monarchy system. They have economy centred on timber, woodcarvings, they hunt wild boars in the forests which is an eagerly sought after commodity for the furs and meat.

Myrmidens was founded by settlers from Luccinni in Tilea and named in honour of the goddess Myrmidia, it is one of the largest realms of the Borderlands and a traditional naval enemy of Achaes, and keeps the Sartosian pirates and Greenskin raiders away from Tilea.

The Castellumos, or 'Castle' in Myken, is the military center for the region, housing most of a Myken lord's levies and retinues, as well as some servants. Due to the increasing in Tilean pressure on the Mykens, many Castellumoi employ large amounts of artisans or philosophers, adopting and melding the Tilean and Myken arts together into a fascinating blend.

The Akritai are the main skirmishing force for the Myken armies, equipped with javelins, crossbows, and sometimes even long bows. Like most Myken soldiery, these troops are professional soldiers, with paid saleries and terms for service, most signing a 5 year term, with the chance of either retiring after or continuing service and being promoted to a more prestigious rank. Akritai however, are much more loose in this regard, and many are Game wardens or hunters during times of peace, giving them an edge in the dark woods of Stygia or in the scorching heat of the badlands.

The Comitos, or Comitoi, are the heavy standing infantry force of the Mykens, and are second in prestige only to the Excubitoroi. Like the Akritai and Excubitoroi, they have paid saleries and terms for service, but unlike the Akritai, it is not uncommon for Comitoi to be rewared small plots of land in return for their services in war, in addition to their saleries, making them stubborn defenders that do not retreat easily.

The Excubitoroi guard are the finest horsemen in the borderlands and badlands, only surpassed by the Arabyans in the south in horsemanship, of which the Excubitoroi learn much from. These guards are the highest in the Myken tier system, and many are either minor nobles or wealthy merchant sons looking for honor and glory, or, in the case of the captains of the guard, the lord or lady's ear. Heavily armoured, incredibly disciplined, these riders make quick work of any Orkish or Beastman horde that dares to encroach upon a Myken's land.

The Limetatoi, or 'garrison', are those that guard the Limes of a Myken lord or lady's border, and are normally a citizen's first line of defense against any invading threat. Not terribly armoured, nor incredibly disciplined, the Limetatoi's job is to just hold the line until the Comitoi and Excubitoroi arrive to clean up the invaders.

Myken Scutarii are the only militia units in a Myken army, being composed entirely of spears, and in some cases pikes, Scutarii are only raised in cities, and are most similar to the Bretonnian peasant levies in terms of quality and equipment. While they would most certainly lose in a one on one fight, the Scutarii's job is mostly for holding ground and stopping cavalry, something their spears and pikes allow them to do very well.

The Ballistarii are crossbow wielding heavy skirmisher troops designed to kill other skirmisher and heavy infantry formations with their powerful siege crossbows. Due to the close relationship between the Mykens and the dwarfs, the Ballistarii's crossbows are of superior make compared to the Estalian or Tilean models, easily puncturing plate mail and in some cases being forceful enough to pass through multiple targets.

The Atamoi are the wealthy sons of merchants or ruler republican leaders, pressed into service so that the merchantile class may receive more recognition for their services to their lord or lady. They are not as heavily armoured or disciplined as the Excubitoroi, but make good units for harassing armies and chasing down fleeing enemies.

A Myken city is an intriqueing sight to behold for any traveller visitng the Borderlands. In stark contrast between the grim outlook of many minor villages and forts in the area, Myken cities are centers of trade, science, and philosophy, attracting many to their centers and increasing the power that each city wields, many of which could be rivalling city states, if not for the constant Ork or Beastman threat. Due to the increased cultural pressures from Tilea, many Myken cities are adopting and melding the modern look of a Tilean city with the ancient splendours of the old Myken cities.

The Grand Academia is the philosophical and intellectual center of all Myrmidian cities, housing hundreds of scholars, scientists, and philosophers. Many nobles and merchants send their sons to these establishments, universities specializing in the fine arts, engineering, and the art of war. Such a quality education is not cheap, however...

Sigmar Heldenhammer is the legendary founder of the Empire, its patron God, and spiritual defender. Although his cult attracts few followers from other parts of the Old World, it is the most influential cult in the Empire. Increasing their influence will bring fierce templars to defend your holdings.

Ulric is a fierce god, patron of wolves and winter, and special protector of the northern part of Sigmar's Empire. His Cult is powerful and popular among soldiers throughout the Old World, but their direct approach sometimes limits their reach. As the Cult of Ulric expands in your realm, its ferocious templars will flock to your banner.

Tor is the god of thunder and lightning in the Old World. He is also worshipped as a warrior god, and is revered in the nation of Kislev. He is portrayed as a muscled, square-jawed warrior. He wields a massive axe with a haft of oak, and uses it to cleave the sky to create the thunderbolts for which he is famed.

Ursun is the most revered God of Kislev, for he is considered Kislev's principle War God and the primary God of the ancient Gospodars when they still lived in their original homeland within the Eastern Steppes.

Bretonnia is dotted with Grail Chapels. These shrines commemorate places where the Lady of the Lake has appeared to her faithful and are most often the sites at which a Knight drank from the Grail and joined Bretonnia's holiest order. The majority of Grail Chapels are neglected, but by investing in this site you can attract cohorts of fanatical Grail Pilgrims.

Dazh is the God of Fire and Sun and whose worship is primarily based within the cold, frigid lands of Kislev. It was Dazh who took the secret of flame from the sun and gave it to the ancient warrior chiefs of the tribesmen. Without Dazh’s fire, the long winters of the north would be fatal, and tributes and prayers are regularly offered up to him. In more civilised lands, he rules over the hearths of homes, and is also the patron of guests and the needy.
The Lares are the small gods of Tilea, a community of ancestor spirits that watches over every household. This folk religion is the touchstone of Tilea's independent, fractious spirit.
Santiago de Vivar is the national saint of Estalia, a great hero of the resistance to Arabyan invasion. Centuries later, shrines to his memory still attract and inspire knights.

Myrmidia the Spear-Maiden is most popular in the southern lands of Estalia and Tilea, but her cult attracts warriors from across the Old World. Unlike the warrior cults of Sigmar and Ulric, Myrmidia's faithful focus on the arts of strategy. Indeed, their goddess is revered as a patron of all civilized arts. As the Cult of Myrmidia expands in your lands, it brings with it warriors and military technology.

Taal and Rhya are ancient Gods of Nature, most popular in Talabecland. However, their worshippers can be found in rural areas throughout the Old World. The Cult of Taal and Rhya attracts hardy woodsmen and rangers.

Shallya the Bleeding Heart is the Goddess of Mercy and Healing. She is popular throughout the Old World (including in Kislev, where she is known as Salyak). Shallya is especially prominent in Bretonnia where her tenderness is the only relief to suffering peasants. While expanding the influence of the Shallyan Cult will not attract many soldiers, their good works will reflect well upon you and help the local economy.

Morr is the God of the Dead and Dreamers, an ominous deity who none the less protects the souls of men from the Dark Gods. His Cult is widespread though largely unconcerned with politics. Increasing the influence of the Morrian Cult will establish their black-armoured templars as a firm line of defence against the forces of Undeath and Chaos.

Manann is the Lord of the Seas. He is the God granted dominion over the waters, and though he is sometimes fickle his patronage is essential to those who ply the waves or dwell by them. Increasing the influence of his wealthy Cult will bring extra revenue to your coffers and make more ships available to your fleet.

Verena is the cultured Goddess of Knowledge and Law. Her Cult is small and scattered, but they are highly influential due to their learning and wisdom. Endowing the Cult of Verena's libraries will help your counties to develop technology.

The people of Kislev are a superstitious folk, and those that ministrate such superstition within a settlement are known by the Ungol tribes collectively as Wise Women. These Wise Women are an ancient tradition of magicians that still survives among the Ungols tribes, and their influence extends even to the Gospodars. The wise women keep the oral lore of the tribes, mediate with the spirits of the steppe, and keep a vigilant eye out for the taint of Chaos. Naturally, everyone hates them. That is, of course, a slight exaggeration, but no where are the wise women, or the hags, actually popular. Wise women know much of the history of the Ungol tribes and of their dealings with the creatures of the steppes. They use this knowledge to help the tribe. In some areas, the ability to recollect such information might make them popular, but on the northern steppes of Kislev, their knowledge consists almost entirely of past disasters and the depredations of the servants of the Ruinous Powers. Thus, their advice almost always consists of telling people they cannot do things that look like a good idea. That valley might look sheltered and fertile, but it was home to a cult that bound Daemons. Travelling south with the horses might earn a fortune, but if the rota does not perform a particular ritual, then the ghosts of a raiding band of Kurgan will be freed to come after them. And so on.
A Strigoi lingers within this province. The old and bitter undead has found home in some obscure necropolis or subterranean fortress. Likely a labyrintine complex not easy to access.
The Necrarchs spend most of their time hiding in well protected and obscurely-located wizard towers, enwrapped in traps and protection spells which make them all but impregnable.

Silver Pinnacle, mirror of her palace in Lahmia. In the innermost chambers, which are lit by torches, she has rebuilt the splendour of that ancient city. The scents of burning incense and perfumed oils fill the air. The walls are covered in hieroglyphics picked out with gemstones and gold. Statues with lapis lazuli eyes stare down at beautiful Vampire handmaidens wearing the clothes of Nehekhara. Here, Neferata idly pulls the strings that change history, whilst she drinks the blood of beautiful youths and listens to the music her Undead children make. Surrounding the court is a network of trapped passages and Undead guards covered from head to toe in black. Only those mortals of the queen's choosing are allowed past them.

Vampire's Cove, built upon the old ruins of Huatl, is a hub for pirate activity in central Lustria. Huatl was but a ruin of the Lizardmen, but once Luther Harkon and his undead pirate crew arrived, they conquered the stretch of Lustrian coastline now known as the Vampire coast. It is now as rich or powerful as any other coastal settlement, in no small thanks to being ruled by an immortal vampire.
Mindless forms of undead tend to instinctively gather around vampires like moths to a light, ready to obey their dark masters' commands.
A pack of ghouls has gathered in this province, feeding on the local populace in exchange for its utter obedience to the local vampire lord.
The Sylvanian vampires are well known for building vast and grotesque fortresses, large enough for them to entertain themselves in all those activities that mortals usually partake in the outside.

The Fimir are an ancient race of Cyclops-like, half-daemonic monsters that inhabit the marshes and bogs of the old world. Long ago, these twisted and evil creatures were the chosen servants of the Dark Gods, but when the first of Mankind arrived, the Fimir lost the favor of their patrons, and their dark empire fell. Now, most live in Ruined, Desolate fortresses and castles deep in the bogs and marshes of the old world.
The Shearl are the lowest in the Fimir caste system, being the 'drones' of the race. They are a stupid, slow-witted bunch, and are mostly used as chaff for the nobles and warriors.

The Fimm are the second highest class in the Fimir caste system, being the warriors and nobles of the race. While they are about as intelligent as an Ork, they have the same brutish strength and behaviour, easily overpowering a man.

The Dirach are the third highest class of the Fimir caste system, being the wizards and priests of the race. Much like the Meargh, they are highly intelligent, and the Dirach are capable of controlling and binding Daemons to their services, such as Nuckelavees. While not as powerful as a trained Human wizard, Dirach are still very deadly, and can demolish scores of soldiers in seconds.

While the Shearl do not wear armor into battle, the Fimm, Dirach, and Meargh do wear rudimenary armor and have some quality weapons to use, but most of these arms and wears come from the long abandon stocks of their home, left when the previous inhabitants either died or abandon the fortress.
Beneath a blackened sky, with malice in their soul, the Druchii make ready for war.

Qu'ittax is the largest Miyan-inhabited ruin in Lustria, and used to be an important city-temple of the Lizardmen. A great pit full of teeth and jagged rocks lies at it's center, where the Miyan perform bloody rituals to honour their ravenous god, Kukaili.

Ganaina is the largest Amazon stronghold in Lustria, and the most important religious center as well. The core of this settlement is a collection of ancient pyramids and towers built by the Old Ones. This complex extends deep into the earth, creating a labyrinth of linked underground vaults full of the wonders left by their creators. The two largest pyramids looming over the settlement are the Queen's Palace and the Temple of Rigg. The Temple of Rigg is the heart of the Amazon faith, and the center of their teaching and instruction.

Miyan blowdart warriors are mustered here. Blowdarts are simple tools, but these barbaric halflings have been able to perfect its uses into an art-form, with weekly competitions, with the winner usually getting to eat a prisoner after all is said and done. They wear mostly padded armor, but also wear striking masks to frighten their enemies and bring them luck on the battlefield. Their darts are tipped with poison from the most poisonous plants and frogs in the area, and it is considered a great honor to not only catch the frogs and tip darts in their poison, but also eat them...

The military engineers of Cathay are known to produce some of the finest weapons of war, where the equally skilled marksmen can equipped with them. Here they can practice with their powerful and renown repeating arbalests.

Sudenburg is one of the richest merchant cities of the Southlands and the only colony of Old Worlders that survived the backlash of the Bretonnian Crusades. Once a cosmopolitan meeting point of the different Arabyan, Southlander and Westerlander cultures, it has turned into a full Sigmarite city after the machinations of the Mahtmasi nearly caused its destruction.

The Graf of Sudenburg granted the temple of Samur to the Knight-Captain who saved his city from the Mahtmasi's spells and prevented a war against the city-states of Olohrad and Al-Anaim in the XIX century. Since then, the Witch Hunters have been a constant presence in Sudenburg, keeping in check the influence of the undead lurking in the swamps around it.

Al-Haikk is traditionally the capital of Araby, whenever the nation is united. Once known as the ?Jewel of Araby?, the city has declined importance in recent years, with continued wars, disasters and sieges targeting it due its source of legitimacy as the seat of the Great Sultan of All-Araby. While it?s usually called the ?City of Thieves? nowadays, due to the rampant depopulation ? and thievery ? in some of its old quarters, and overshadowed by other thriving rival cities, it remains a prestigious location to all Arabyans.

The thick outer walls of a Chaos Dwarf Ziggurat are made out of the same dark obsidian as the rest of the structure. While common obsidian is known to be brittle, the Dawi Zharr have perfected their obsidian bricks into a strong material, thanks to their magical skill, alchemy and other darker, sorcerous secrets. As such, these towering walls strike an imposing visage amongst the enemies ? and slaves ? of the Chaos Dwarfs.

While most Human architecture cannot compete with those of the elder races, the Imperials can say with pride that theirs are fairly close to dwarf stock. Elegant, yet intimidating, Imperial castles are normally situated on points of strategic importance, such as river forks or high Plateaus. Like Tilean palaces of the south, Imperial castles have a small cadre of artists, scientists, and engineers to upkeep the castle.

Like their Bretonnian counterparts, Imperial castles will normally have villages and hamlets outside their walls, for the castle can provide some safety to the villagers below. Unlike their Bretonnian counterparts, however, is that these villagers can move around freely, stimulating trade and spreading new ideas throughout the Empire.

The grand city of Nuln is the centre of production for blackpowder weapons and accessories in the Empire with even many dwarfs taking up residence here to lend a hand in both producing and designing many of these weapons.

The great slave markets of the Druchii are places of pain and depravity, where the master's leash cuts deep and the very air thick with malice. Here, slaves are corraled into various stocks and pens, awaiting their fates, weither it be to die toiling in mines, dying in battle, or worse yet, becoming another plaything for their new Druchii masters.

The Ald-Drakk-Bar are a series of ancient fortifications locaed in the Norscan mountains. Likely built by the original Dwarf settlers when they first arrived in Norsca, these gates protect choke-points and important holds from harm.
Norscans are not known to field cavalry, instead relying upon mercenaries from their more northerly brethren to fill the gaps.

The main keeps of Tilean fortresses are usually ostentatious palaces built by its myriad of Princes. While they lack the typical garrison of armoured footmen and free riders of other realms, they make up with a veritable army of philosophers, painters, sculptors and other polymaths seeking patronage, who make the abodes of Tliean princes into true cultural ? and financial - centers.
This castle has set it's focus to fielding Gunner regiments.
Thanks to this holding's focus, it is providing Gunner regiments for our armies.
This castle has set it's focus to fielding Artillery regiments.
This castle has set it's focus to fielding War Elephant regiments.
Thanks to this holding's focus, it is providing War Elephant regiments for our armies.
Halflings rarely go to war, but preparations are made nonetheless. The sheriff's office is also used to store weapons, house fighters, and train militia.
Even if there aren't any dedicated fighters about, one can always find Halflings ready to defend their homes.
Sharp-eyed Halflings are recruited and trained as scouts and guards. Specialising in archery, some brave Halflings also learn to ride ponies into battle, called Hobilars.

Rather than forcing Halflings into long, brunchless days of training, it is possible to simply drag as many as possible from their homes at the time of crisis. The effect of a great many angry, hungry Halflings defending their dinners are not to be underestimated.

The Hot-Pie Catapult is an intersting Halfling invention, made out of desperation by a Halfling cook when he came under attack by a Goblin force. He would eventually win the battle, in thanks to his makeshift artillery units that fired incredibly hot pies at the goblins, which proved to be surprisingly effective against them. Ever since the battle, the temples and shrines to Esmeralda always have a small number of these catapults, in case they come under attack.

The armory is one of the main pieces of any Imperial castle or city, used to house all of the armor and weapons that will later be used to equip the province's militia units. This one lacks any sort of proper equipment, diminishing the militia's fighting abilities.

The armory is one of the main pieces of any Imperial castle or city, used to house all of the armor and weapons that will later be used to equip the province's militia units. This one has weapons of some quality in it's stock, improving the fighting abilities of the province's militia.

The armory is one of the main pieces of any Imperial castle or city, used to house all of the armor and weapons that will later be used to equip the province's militia units. This one has weapons of superb quality in it's stock, greatly improving the fighting abilities of the province's militia.

Unlike the State Troops, whom are professional soldiers payed to fight, Imperial Free Companies are composed almost entirely of militia, that is, hunters, farmers, and so on. While they are not trained to fight, and are not as well equipped as the State Troops, Free Companies are normally raised when times are dire, and so these might fight for their homes, instead of money.

Unlike the State Troops, whom are professional soldiers payed to fight, Imperial Free Companies are composed almost entirely of militia, that is, hunters, farmers, and so on. While they are not trained to fight, and are not as well equipped as the State Troops, Free Companies are normally raised when times are dire, and so these might fight for their homes, instead of money.

The Empire is full of forests and woodlands, some of which are more dangerous than others. From these places the Imperials recruit their archers, dead accurate with their bows, they are nothing to scoff at.

In the Empire, education is taken more seriously among the nobility than in other regions such as Bretonnia or Tilea and Estalia. As such, a cadre of academicians and engineers is common place in the castles of the Empire.

In the Empire, education is taken more seriously among the nobility than in other regions such as Bretonnia or Tilea and Estalia. As such, a cadre of academicians and engineers is common place in the castles of the Empire.

The Grand Order of the Reiksguard are a prestigious, elite order of knights that fight for any emperor of the Reikland or Reiklander emperor. Their ranks are open to everyone, but only the best of the best are chosen to join their ranks, and the effect this has on their units is seen in the field. Utterly loyal, brilliant warriors, and unwavering in the face of evil, these riders are a force to be reckoned with.

The Grand Order of the Reiksguard are a prestigious, elite order of knights that fight for any emperor of the Reikland or Reiklander emperor. Their ranks are open to everyone, but only the best of the best are chosen to join their ranks, and the effect this has on their units is seen in the field. Utterly loyal, brilliant warriors, unwavering in the face of evil, and crack shots, these foot soldiers are a force to be reckoned with.

Due to the Reikland's position in the Empire, and places such as Ubersreik, Bogenhafen, and Altdorf, the Reikland is a very rich place, and many nobles and emperors have used this wealth to build large armories for their soldiers.
Thanks to Nuln, Wissenlander militias can maintain regiments of black powder troops, armed with the famous Nuln repeating rifle.
Due to bordering both the Black and Grey mountains, Wissenland has access to a large amount of metals, which allows them to fortify their walls and better protect their soldiers

With Nuln being a major trading hub in the southern Empire, there are many trade routes to and from the city, and each requires a guard to protect the merchants and travellers. In times of war, these riders can be levied into the state militias offering their quick hit-and-run skills to the armies that use them.

Due to Marienburg's title of center of trade in the Empire, merchant ships require elite troops that can defend their goods on the seas. Heavily armed, and used to fighting on the seas, Westerlander marines can also be used to fight on land as well as at sea.

the Westerlands are a harsh, and barren lands unsuited for major farming or even logging. This forces the majority of the population to take to the seas, with these shipyards being the lifeblood of the Westerland, delivering foodstuffs and other materials not found in the Westerlands.

Thanks to Marienburg, trade flows to and through the city all across the Empire, but many greedily eye such treasures, wanting it all for themselves. With these Watchtowers, trade can be secured and protected.

Long ago, before Solland was destroyed by the hands of Greenskins, Solland was a well respected Elector-County, rich and powerful due to their trade from the south. But, with Solland destroyed, many of the displaced nobles donned black armor and began forming into what they called Black Rider companies. They assist Sollanders whenever they can, and are a feared fighting force in the field.

Much like Black Rider companies, Auffrischer companies are Sollanders whom have taken up sword, pike, and shield in an effort to restore their lost glory. Due to this, they are not easily broken, and will fight like a wounded animal to protect their home and hearth.

In the days of old, Solland was a hub of trade activity in the south of the Empire thanks to the trading destination of Nuln. The old trade roads still see use by merchants, but a presistant lord can invest in the roads to encourage merchants to travel the roads like in the days of old.

Averland has a proud martial history, being the descendents of the Brigundians, masters of chariot and cavalry warfare. While they may no longer use chariots, and the nobles may be the only ones that can afford to use the heavy weapons and armor, the free companies of Averland are nothing to bat the eye at, for they will hold their position, no matter what is thrown at them

Averland is a place of rolling hills and fertile grasslands for as far as the eye can see. Thanks to this, Averland has many farms and mansions spread out across it's lands, to which they use to feed themselves and the rest of the Empire.

Long ago, Averland was populated by the Brigundians, masters of cavalry warfare, providing Sigmar with his elite cavalry forces needed to unite the Empire and defend it. While the Brigundians are no more, their traditions remain a proud, dutifuly practiced tradition among the nobility of Averland, producing some of the finest horsemen in all of the Empire.

Stirland is a county deeply rooted in tradition and superstition, believing completely in the age old saying 'If it ain't broke, don't fix it'. This is mirrored in their free companies, who are stubborn attackers and defenders in any situation.

Death Watch is an unofficial order of undead hunters that scour the lands of Stirland hunting the evil things that lurk in the night. They are made up of mostly peasants, whom are given formal training and the equipment required to hunt such beasts.

Stirland is a poor and barbaric land, unsuitable for farming and trading. So instead, the peasantry take to hunting, and due to Stirland's proximity to Sylvania, these hunters are hardend souls used to seeing monstrous horrors that would make a normal man run for his life, some even actively hunt said beasts.

Talabecland is a realm that is swallowed whole by the Great Forest, the largest of five great forests in the Empire. Like all of the forests, it harbors untold amounts of bandits, Greenskins, Beastmen, and even sometimes Chaos warriors should an invasion fail. Due to this, Talabecland has formed an elite archer unit comprised of the local hunters, tasked with hunting and exterminating any dark threats that lurk in the shadows of the Great Forests of the Empire.

While the Empire continues to try and contain the vast forests that grow within it's borders, it is sometimes neglectful of it's roads that criss-cross the entirety of the Empire. Traveling the Empire in good times can take weeks, especially going through Woodland Roads. Due to the sheer amount of danger inhabiting these forests, stopping to rest in the middle of nowhever is impracticle, so the Elector-Counties-Talabecland especially- have established fortified coaching inns along the roads for merchants and travellers to rest in safety.

Thanks to Talabecland being almost completely consumed by the Great Forest, logging has become a norm in the Elector-County. While it provides money and supplies to the county, it isn't exactly a safe job, with bandits, Greenskins, and even Beastmen roaming the dark places of the forest, so each lumberjack is skilled in the use of a bow-and-arrow, and can be levied in times of war to support the militia of Talabecland.

Drakwald is a harsh, and unforgiving land, it's people tempered by the forest, and long remember their ancestors, the Thuringians. This life-style is reflected in it's Free Companies, hardy and unshakable. Drakwalder companies are mostly gunpowder and archer units, as the Drakwald forest engulfs all of the county of Drakwald.

The Ehrw?rdige Krieger, or venerable warriors, are Drakwald's finest soldiers. Having served in other Free companies for years, and returned to Drakwald to etch a life out of it's dark forests, these warriors are as unshakable as the mountains, and inspire others to follow in their footsteps.

The Drakwald is, for the most part, an isolated province, cut off from much of the rest of the empire, thanks to it's namesake forest. Due to this, many of the traditions of old still go on in the county, with the militias forming professional Heerbanns instead of militia units that the rest of the Empire uses.

The White Wolves of Middenland are an elite order, tasked with defending the Ar-Ulric and Middenland from harm. Each has sworn the oath of Ulric, and each have seen years of service in defense of the Middenland and the Ar-Ulric, making them a formidable force on the field of battle.

Like most of the northern Imperial counties, the Middenland has a long and proud martial tradition. Middenlander Greatswords are the finest soldiers of Middenland, and they would tell you they are the best in all of the Empire, and can back it up with their ferocity and will on the battlefield.

Thanks to Middenland's close proximity to the Drakwald, the Great Forest, and the Shadow forest, logging has become a norm in the Elector-County. While it provides money and supplies to the county, it isn't exactly a safe job, with bandits, Greenskins, and even Beastmen roaming the dark places of the forest, so each lumberjack is skilled in the use of a bow-and-arrow, and can be levied in times of war to support the militia of Middenladnd.

The Nordland, much like all counties in the north of the Empire, is a hard land, with the only constants being strife and death. While it does not have to bear the brunt of Chaos incursions, it is constantly pillaged and raided by the Norscans. But not all of them leave, as some settle down in the Nordland, bringing with them their belongings and traditions, of which the Nordland has adopted in the form of it's Warbands and Beserkers. High on some fort of shrooms and bloodlust, Beserkers throw themselves willingly into the frey with little regard for safety, carving bloody swaths into enemy formations.

Nordland is under constant threat from the Norscans to the north, raiding and pillaging villages and merchants in it's lands. Born out of desperation, the Nordland has established coastal guards to intercept the raiders before they land on it's shores, hoping to provide even a momentary respite from the constant raids from the north.

The Nordland, while sparsly populated, is home to not only Imperials, but Norscans as well that have been permitted to settle in the county. Due to this mix of cultures, Nordland does not field 'militias' but instead raises warbands, semi-professional soldiers that serve terms. Undisciple and barbaric, these soldiers are much more aggressive than their southern counterparts, but can be relied upon to hold a line or crush the enemy lines.

The reknown Hochland Long rifle companies are trained here, providing the state militia and Imperial armies with invaluable accurate, long range support. Crack shots, these sharpshooters can harass blocks of units just as well as harassing officers cores.

Not to be confused with Leon Todmeister's Fantabulously Far reaching Harquebus of Unforeseeable and Unperceived Bereavement, these hunters are armed with Hochland long rifles, which are handguns instead of fixed rifles. Much like the fixed rifles however, the handguns have superb accuracy and can fire at longer ranges than most standard Imperial handguns, making them excellent supporting units.

While not nearly as large as the Grey and Black mountains in the south that border the Wissenland, the Middle mountains are still rich with minerals, and better yet, are not filled with Dwarf Karaks, meaning the mineral rights do not have to be shared, and allow for more minerals to be extracted from the mountains.

The Desperate Sons are Sylvania's 'free companies'. With Sylvania being a poor and backward county, these free companies are truly a desperate lot, more often not even being able to afford the proper uniform, let alone weapons. But what they don't have in weapons and armor, they make up for in spirit, for they have lived all their lives in the cursed lands of Sylvania, they have nothing to fear.

Much like anything in Sylvania, the Forlorn Hope companies are depressing sights to behold. While they can actually afford weapons and armor, most shun the use of armor, for many within the Hopes' ranks are either criminals, or peasants that have lost their homes or families, and thus have nothing left to live for.

In stark contrast to the peasantry of Sylvania, the nobility are well-off and well groomed, living in impressive castles and living in luxury. However, much like anything in Sylvania, the nobles are expert fighters, sallying out in groups to cleanse their lands of mutants, heretics, and sometimes undead.

Ostermark is the northern most county in the Empire, sitting above Sylvania and to the east of Ostland and Hochland. Due to this, the Ostermark is normally the first to be assailed by marauding Chaos warhosts, and has developed an obsession with death. These horsemen are the embodiment of that obession.

The long history of the Ostermark and the countless invasions from the north it has endured has lead to the development of military tactics that counter the horse-based armies of the Chaos wastes. Pike-and-Shot regiments combine the firepower of gunpowder units with the staying power and protection of Pike units, making them difficult to overcome from the primarly melee cavalry based armies of the Chaos wastes.

After every chaos incursion, there are normally bands of northlanders that pillage and marauder Ostermark's countrysides, causing havoc and being a pain to any noble of the realm. Outriders are the answer to this. Fast, Hard hitting cavalry units that hunt down and destroy any warbands left behind from the incursion.

Ostland has a higher precentage of Ogres living in it's lands than other counties in the empire, many of which are marked as citizens of Ostland. In times of war, Ostland will commonly raise Ogre regiments alongside it's state troops to assist.
The Stur Guard are the Ostland's elite infantry forces. Stubborn as a bull, these warriors do no back down from a fight, and have long held many a Chaos incursion at bay in their homelands.

Due to Ostland being on the road to the Imperial capital, it's people must ever be vigilant against the dark incursions from the north, and have thus erected watchtowers along it's northern borders so that it may be warned ahead of time if such an invasion should accure.
The 'Neue' towns are impressive centers of trade in their own right, encompassing large amounts of different cultures and faiths, these towns are rich and power.

Rough Riders are semi-professional cavalry units that patrol the borders of Neueslander lands for Bandits, Greenskins, and Beastmen. Due to the large amount of Neueslanders in the Border Princedoms, they commonly fight Greenskins, and have become experts at killing said Greenskins.

The Engineer Academy is much like the merchantile and military academies found in Imperial castles, except that instead of noble sons, it is the rich merchant sons that attend. The academicians are some of the brightest architects and engineers of the Empire, and thus help shore up the cities' walls and provide some artillery for the defenses.

In the absence of proper infrastructure or trustworthy vassals, it can sometimes be necessary to levy the peasantry into service. Although poor in combat, it is better than nothing.

The local levy are combined with sellswords and adventurers, creating a cheap yet effective army that can be raised at a moments notice. The high proportion of 'former' bandits, pirates, and criminals means that the levies possess some skill and courage.

Core of any Empire army consists of professional soldiers which are trained and quartered for the service of their lord. Each Elector Count is expected to provide a Imperial Army with troops. Lower rank nobles posses limited amount of professional troops.
